SubTopics: Develop questions to broaden thinking on a specific idea that frames inquiry for new learning and deeper understanding.
Content: A student is writing a report on the effects of listening to music while studying. Read the draft of the report.

:ibox:Studies suggest that some people learn better if they listen to instrumental music while they study. There seems to be a connection between the rhythms of the music and the ability to concentrate. When the music has a steady, repetitive beat, it creates background noise that can be beneficial. Of course, the music cannot be too loud, or it will become distracting.
If the student were conducting additional research, which question would ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß help the student focus the research for a deeper understanding of the subject?

A.Choice: What types of music are the most popular with students who are studying?

B.Choice: How many people participated in the studies about listening to music?

C.Choice: What types of experiments have been done to show the connection between music and learning?

D.Choice: How loud would the music need to be before it is considered too loud to have positive effects?

SubTopics: Cite multiple examples of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: This question has two parts. First, answer part A. Then, answer part B.
Which sentence explains the most likely reason for the newscast containing nonsense?

A.Choice: Gabe is distracted while writing out the news reports on index cards.

B.Choice: Gabe wants to play a joke on the reporters and his middle school.

C.Choice: Gabe mixes up the index cards when he drops them.

D.Choice: Gabe is uncomfortable and reads the news incorrectly.

Content: Which sentence from the passage supports the answer in part A?

A.Choice: He grabbed the pile of index cards, hastily attempted to put them back in order, and headed toward the school's television studio.

B.Choice: Each morning, middle-school students compiled a short live news segment, which was broadcast to every classroom in the school just before classes began.

C.Choice: Relieved to see that the ‚ÄúOn the Air‚Äù sign was not yet on, Gabe took his seat at the news desk beside Marcella, the other regular reporter, and handed her half the stack of index cards.

D.Choice: He had been concerned that, if the words were written too small, he might stumble over them when speaking on camera.

SubTopics: Cite multiple examples of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which ùóßùó™ùó¢ details from the passage most strongly support the reason why Gabe is anxious about the day's newscast? Choose ùóßùó™ùó¢ answers.

A.Choice: Gabe reads news in front of the camera for the first time.

B.Choice: One of the news stories is about a field trip.

C.Choice: Gabe writes down news reports on index cards.

D.Choice: Arun is absent from the news show due to illness.

E.Choice: Marcella is one of the hosts of the news broadcast.

SubTopics: Determine one or more themes and analyze the development; provide an objective summary.
Content: This question has two parts. First, answer part A. Then, answer part B.
What is a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: It is important to be on time.

B.Choice: A good idea can change a bad situation.

C.Choice: Friends help each other no matter what happens.

D.Choice: You should always have more than one plan for success.

Content: Which sentence from the passage ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supports the answer in part A?

A.Choice: He was already running late, and now he was going to have to reorganize all his index cards for the newscast.

B.Choice: ‚ÄúIt's OK,‚Äù she said.

C.Choice: He knew he should have put each complete report on just one card the way he usually did, but he wanted to make his handwriting big enough to read easily.

D.Choice: ‚ÄúYou saved the day in the end.‚Äù

SubTopics: Determine one or more themes and analyze the development; provide an objective summary.
Content: Which paragraph ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß summarizes the passage?

A.Choice: Gabe is running late on his way to take part in the school newscast. He drops the cards that he wrote and has to pick them back up. When he gets to the studio, he has to sit in front of the camera with Marcella. Lani starts the show, but it is very confusing. Then Gabe tells everyone that it is April Fool's Day so that the report can end.

B.Choice: When Gabe is in the crowded hallway, several bad things happen to him. He has to rush to the school television studio to give the daily newscast. He is only reading the news because someone is absent. When the show starts Marcella reads that the students will be taking a field trip to the school track. Gabe knows it is his fault so he tries to solve the problem.

C.Choice: On his way to the school television studio, Gabe has many problems, including dropping his notes. It is his first time reading the news on camera. When Gabe and Marcella start reading the news reports, they do not make sense because the note cards are mixed up. Gabe realizes that he can play off the mistake by claiming it is an April Fool's Day joke as he ends the newscast.

D.Choice: Gabe usually writes the news reports on one card, but today he used large print so that he could see what he wrote better. The cards got mixed up so the newscast did not go as planned. Marcella and Gabe are on camera reading pieces of news that do not belong together. Gabe has an idea to save the day, which makes Marcella and Lani feel better. Gabe knows he will not make that mistake again.

SubTopics: Analyze how setting shapes the characters and/or plot and how particular elements of a narrative or drama interact; determine the impact of contextual influences on setting, plot, and characters.
Content: Which statement ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß explains how the setting of April Fool's Day helps to shape the plot of the passage?

A.Choice: It introduces the internal conflict Gabe feels about being on camera.

B.Choice: It adds suspense by indicating that Gabe knew about the newscast mistake when Lani was unaware.

C.Choice: It leads to the solution of the problem by allowing Gabe to come up with a reason for the newscast mistake.

D.Choice: It clarifies the close friendship that Gabe has with Marcella.

SubTopics: Determine the figurative and connotative meaning of words and phrases as they are used in text; analyze the impact of rhymes and other repetitions of sounds on specific verses or stanzas of poems or sections of narrative or drama.
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.

:ibox:Gabe sat there, feeling frozen, until Lani waved her arms at him frantically from the other side of the camera, urging him to continue. She silently mouthed the words ‚ÄúHurry up! We're live!‚Äù
What does the phrase ‚Äúfeeling frozen‚Äù suggest about Gabe?

A.Choice: Gabe is hiding from others as a joke.

B.Choice: Gabe is concentrating on reporting the news.

C.Choice: Gabe is shivering because he is cold.

D.Choice: Gabe is sitting still because he is nervous.

SubTopics: Analyze the author‚Äôs choice of structures within the text and draw conclusions about how they impact meaning.
Content: How do the events in paragraphs 1‚Äì4 contribute to the meaning of the passage?

A.Choice: They show Gabe as a hardworking student.

B.Choice: They suggest Gabe will experience a difficult day.

C.Choice: They show Gabe enjoys being part of a team.

D.Choice: They suggest Gabe is the director for the school newscast.

SubTopics: Cite multiple examples of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which sentence from the passage ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supports the conclusion that engineers include multiple features to assure that roller coasters are safe for riders?

A.Choice: Wooden coasters can be more affordable to build, and some riders think they are more exciting, since their flexible material tends to sway as the coaster cars travel over it.

B.Choice: According to Andy Boyd at the University of Houston, steel roller coasters can travel as fast as 125 miles per hour, while wooden coasters usually cannot travel faster than 80 miles per hour.

C.Choice: A second set of wheels moves along the sides of these rails, while a third set of wheels moves underneath the rails, keeping the coaster connected to the track no matter whether the coaster car is right-side up or upside down.

D.Choice: Roller-coaster engineers are perpetually searching for ways to make their rides all the more exciting and invigorating.

SubTopics: Provide an objective summary of a text with two or more central ideas; cite key supporting details to analyze their development.
Content: Which statement expresses two central ideas of ‚ÄúThe Roller-Coaster Revolution‚Äù that would ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß fit in a summary of the passage?

A.Choice: The first roller coasters were designed and built in Europe, and their design is said to have originated from wooden slides covered with ice in the city of St. Petersburg.

B.Choice: Roller coasters have served as a form of entertainment for centuries, and protecting riders is one of the main goals of roller-coaster design.

C.Choice: Safety is an important consideration in the design of the tracks and seats of roller coasters, and some wooden and steel coasters are even able to turn riders upside down.

D.Choice: Roller coasters can be found in amusement parks worldwide, and they mainly use energy generated by gravity to propel them around their tracks.

SubTopics: Determine an author‚Äôs perspective or purpose and analyze how the author distinguishes his/her position from others.
Content: Which detail from the passage best reveals the author's perspective on roller coasters?

A.Choice: Because steel is so durable and strong, however, steel roller coasters can be built taller and run faster than wooden ones.

B.Choice: Roller coasters usually reach their fastest speeds at the bottom of this first hill, and the energy from the first drop is enough to propel the car through the rest of the twists and turns of the ride.

C.Choice: As you might imagine, strong brakes are needed to slow the cars down as they reach the end of the ride.

D.Choice: For as long as these engineers improve their technology, roller-coaster riders will seek out the thrill of the latest and greatest rides that are available.

SubTopics: Determine figurative, connotative, and technical meanings of words and phrases used in a text; analyze the impact of specific words or phrases on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 9, how does the word dÕüuÕürÕüaÕütÕüiÕüoÕün impact meaning?

A.Choice: by describing the types of cars

B.Choice: by describing the length of time the ride lasts

C.Choice: by describing the size of the tracks

D.Choice: by describing the position of the riders

SubTopics: Determine the impact of text features and structures on an author‚Äôs ideas or claims.
Content: How does the author's use of the subheading ‚ÄúThe (Safe) Thrill of the Ride‚Äù impact the passage?

A.Choice: It emphasizes a key idea about roller coasters that the author develops.

B.Choice: It reveals the author's opinion that roller coasters are not as exciting as they may seem.

C.Choice: It introduces an explanation of how modern roller coasters compare to the first coasters.

D.Choice: It supports the author's earlier claim that roller coasters have an interesting history.

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which piece of evidence ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß supports the author's claim in paragraph 4 that ‚Äú... it was in the United States that the modern-day coaster was born‚Äù?

A.Choice: The Coney Island ride cost $1600 to build.

B.Choice: A French roller coaster built in 1812 featured attached wheels and track wheels.

C.Choice: A professor at the University of Houston states that steel coasters are capable of going 125 miles per hour.

D.Choice: People began riding downhill on a Pennsylvania coal train in 1827.

SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: Which piece of evidence supports the author's claim that ‚ÄúCareful, creative design is needed, however, to make these coasters exciting yet safe as possible‚Äù?

A.Choice: Back in the 1600s near the city of St. Petersburg in Russia, people used to build tall wooden slides and cover their surfaces with smooth ice.

B.Choice: Historians disagree on whether the first official roller coaster was built in Russia in 1784 or in France in 1812.

C.Choice: There are shoulder harnesses or bars that pull down securely across riders' torsos and legs, holding the riders securely in their seats.

D.Choice: Believe it or not, most roller coaster cars have no engines!

SubTopics: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument.
Content: A student is writing an argument for allowing students to bring water bottles into classes. Read the concluding paragraph.

:ibox:In the end, students would be much better off if they could bring water bottles into their classes. The benefits far outweigh the drawbacks, something on which everyone can agree. _______________.
Which of these sentences would ùóïùóòùó¶ùóß end the paragraph?

A.Choice: Leaving the decision up to the students might even be the best option.

B.Choice: Changing this rule would be a positive step for students and teachers alike.

C.Choice: In fact, people are constantly saying that water bottles would be a good compromise.

D.Choice: For example, people who drink water throughout the day are better able to concentrate.

SubTopics: Develop the topic with relevant facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.
Content: A student is writing a report on the importance of proper footwear for running. Read the paragraph.

:ibox:Running shoes do more than protect a runner's feet against the elements. They also support the body's weight and keep the body in the proper position. That is why it is important to get shoes that feel right for your body. One way to do this is by going into a store to have your stride and weight distribution analyzed.
Which sentence would add additional information to Which sentence would add additional information to best develop the topic? develop the topic?

A.Choice: When you are ready to make a purchase, there are three stores in town that sell a variety of types and brands of running shoes to our athletes.

B.Choice: When my brother went in to find a new pair of running shoes, he told me that certain shoes made him feel like he was running on air.

C.Choice: According to a report in the Journal of Sports Medicine, it is important to try several shoes to determine which are the most comfortable.

D.Choice: In order to keep up with all of the newest shoes on the market, a runner may want to subscribe to a publication like Runners' Weekly.

SubTopics: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting.
Content: A student is writing an essay about letter writing. Read part of the essay.

:ibox:Years ago, before cell phones or computers, people used to write letters to friends who lived far away. The people to whom the letters were addressed opened them with joy. It made them feel good to know that someone thought enough about them to take the time to sit down and to put their thoughts on paper. Those times have almost disappeared. Writing letters is quickly becoming a lost art form. Today, people prefer to communicate with others by calling, by texting, or send emails.
What is the correct way to revise the last sentence of the paragraph?

A.Choice: Today, people prefer to communicate with others by calling, by text, or by sending emails.

B.Choice: Today, people prefer to communicate with others by calling, texting, or sending emails.

C.Choice: Today, people prefer to communicate with others by calls, by texts, or by sending emails.

D.Choice: Today, people prefer to communicate with others by calling, by texting, or also by sending emails.

SubTopics: Use phrases and clauses within a sentence, recognizing and correcting misplaced and dangling modifiers.
Content: Read the paragraph.

:ibox:Not long ago, I decided I needed more exercise, so I began riding my bicycle almost every day. I like to ride on old country roads because there is a lot to see. Last Saturday morning, I saw a horse riding my bicycle down the street. What a magnificent animal it was!
Which revision corrects the misplaced modifier in the paragraph?

A.Choice: Last Saturday morning, while riding my bicycle down the street, I saw a horse.

B.Choice: I saw a horse riding my bicycle down the street last Saturday morning.

C.Choice: Last Saturday morning, just down the street, I saw a horse riding my bicycle.

D.Choice: I saw a horse riding my bicycle last Saturday morning down the street.

SubTopics: Use a comma after introductory subordinate clauses.
Content: Which sentence uses a comma correctly?

A.Choice: After a while, Jimmy grew tired and fell asleep.

B.Choice: I usually eat a big breakfast, on Saturday mornings.

C.Choice: I was dressed and ready, an hour before the school bus arrived.

D.Choice: Before, Sherri could leave the house she had to make sure all of her chores were finished.
